infoText: Statue of Nelson Mandela at the Capetown City Hall.

All the houses in this neighborhood are painted bright colors. Although the neighborhood was occupied by "Africans and coloreds" (still terms used by South Africans today), they were not allowed to own property under Apartheid.  Instead, they leased the houses from white landlords. When the people who lived here were finally allowed to purchase property, they painted the houses bright colors as an expression of their freedom. The houses are repainted regularly, still with bright, vibrant colors.
Nathan Chikoto Recycle Artist Still in the neighborhood. This artists makes art out of recycled materials.
This is a model of neighborhood itself, made out of scrap metal.
From old soft drink cans. You can see the colors of Coca Cola cans in some of them.
Scenic view on the way the Cape of Good Hope.
Cape of Good Hope At the Cape of Good Hope! Notice I am behind the sign, so am even farther southwest.
At the top of the mountain at Cape Point. It was very cloudy to start out so we didn't think we'd see much, but it cleared up quickly!
Pole at the top, near the lighthouse.
I decided to walk down instead of riding the funicular.  I was glad I did when I saw the amazing views!

Boulders Park Boulders Park is home of the African Penguin! This is one of the few places African penguins can be found. They are also known as the Jackass Penguin, due to the loud, donkey-like noise they make.
title: Boulders Park

infoText: On the way to Boulders Park, we found some baboons!
All the baboon photos are taken through a window, but some of them came out well anyway.
My first siting was a fuzzy baby penguin hiding out in a hole.
